content.raw: I don't really understand all the conventions within simspark, I can just tell you if gazebo matches simspark:)
content.html: I don't really understand all the conventions within simspark, I can just tell you if gazebo matches simspark:)

content.raw: I see. We could simply flip the sign here too. What I'm confused about is that the combination of directions which you're porposing doesn't seem to follow the right-hand rule.
content.html: I see. We could simply flip the sign here too. What I'm confused about is that the combination of directions which you're porposing doesn't seem to follow the right-hand rule.

content.raw:
* standing up: +9.8 on Z
* up-side down: -9.8 on Z
* Laying on its back: -9.8 on X
* Laying on its front: +9.8 on X
* Laying on its right side: +9.8 on Y
* Laying on its left side: -9.8 on Y

In the screen shots of gazebo showing accel readings the only thing that needs to be changed is to flip the sign of the X axis
content.html:
• standing up: +9.8 on Z
  • up-side down: -9.8 on Z
  • Laying on its back: -9.8 on X
  • Laying on its front: +9.8 on X
  • Laying on its right side: +9.8 on Y
  • Laying on its left side: -9.8 on Y

In the screen shots of gazebo showing accel readings the only thing that needs to be changed is to flip the sign of the X axis

content.raw:
Ok, then let's forget about the documentation. Can you summarize the acceleration readings you expect?

* standing up: +9.8 on Z
* up-side down: -9.8 on Z
* Laying on its back:
* Laying on its front:
* Laying on its right side:
* Laying on its left side:
content.html:
Ok, then let's forget about the documentation. Can you summarize the acceleration readings you expect?

  • standing up: +9.8 on Z
  • up-side down: -9.8 on Z
  • Laying on its back:

content.raw: I've never looked at the model before, but I do know in simspark that x is forward/backward and y is left/right.  The documentation in simpark tends to be outdated and a bit questionable at times.
content.html: I've never looked at the model before, but I do know in simspark that x is forward/backward and y is left/right. The documentation in simpark tends to be outdated and a bit questionable at times.

content.raw:
According to Simspark's [documentation](http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Models):

* +Y = front
* -Y = back
* +X = right
* -X = left

which  I believe is both different from what's currently in Gazebo and from what you said. We can rotate it in here, I wonder how we didn't notice that before.

![Models_NaoBoxModel.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2328853775-Models_NaoBoxModel.png)
content.html:
According to Simspark's documentation:

  • +Y = front
  • -Y = back
  • +X = right
  • -X = left

which I believe is both different from what's currently in Gazebo and from what you said. We can rotate it in here, I wonder how we didn't notice that before.

content.raw: I agree with your logic about the X asix, however based on simspark's conventions it looks like the sign for the X axis should be flipped as the robot has a -X on its back and a +X when on its front.  If forgot that our agent flips the sign of the Y axis after parsing the data and so your values for the Y axis look correct.
content.html: I agree with your logic about the X asix, however based on simspark's conventions it looks like the sign for the X axis should be flipped as the robot has a -X on its back and a +X when on its front. If forgot that our agent flips the sign of the Y axis after parsing the data and so your values for the Y axis look correct.

content.raw:
When you say the Z accel looks correct, are you getting around +9.8 on Z when the robot is standing?

If the expectation is for +9.8 on Z when the torso is upright, then it should be +9.8 on X when the robot is laying on its back, right? Here are some screenshots where you can see the orientation of the torso and the accelerations measured by the IMU. Let me know which ones still seem incorrect:

# Torso upright - around +9.8 on Z
![nao_sitting.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/1661006613-nao_sitting.png)

# Torso lying on its right side - around +9.8 on Y

![nao_right_side.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/3263034207-nao_right_side.png)

# Torso lying on its front - around -9.8 on X

![nao_front.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/3972551463-nao_front.png)

# Torso lying on its back - around +9.8 on X

![nao_back.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/1540997840-nao_back.png)
content.html:
When you say the Z accel looks correct, are you getting around +9.8 on Z when the robot is standing?

If the expectation is for +9.8 on Z when the torso is upright, then it should be +9.8 on X when the robot is laying on its back, right? Here are some screenshots where you can see the orientation of the torso and the accelerations measured by the IMU. Let me know which ones still seem incorrect:

Torso upright - around +9.8 on Z

Torso lying on its right side - around +9.8 on Y

Torso lying on its front - around -9.8 on X

Torso lying on its back - around +9.8 on X

content.raw: The Z accel reading looks correct.  The X and Y accel readings seem to be flipped however.  When the robot has fallen on its back and is facing upward it should have a negative X accel reading while currently this shows up as a positive Y accel reading.  If the robot has fallen on its stomach and is facing down it should have a positive X accel reading (this is showing up as a negative Y accel value).  If a robot has fallen on its left side, with its right side facing up, it should have a positive Y accel reading, and if a robot has fallen on its right side it should have a negative Y accel reading.
content.html: The Z accel reading looks correct. The X and Y accel readings seem to be flipped however. When the robot has fallen on its back and is facing upward it should have a negative X accel reading while currently this shows up as a positive Y accel reading. If the robot has fallen on its stomach and is facing down it should have a positive X accel reading (this is showing up as a negative Y accel value). If a robot has fallen on its left side, with its right side facing up, it should have a positive Y accel reading, and if a robot has fallen on its right side it should have a negative Y accel reading.
